titleStmt.title: Tamiḻneṟi Viḷakkam 17.
Experimenting with formatting for the final edition.

witness.expan: A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [ante correctionem]
A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [post correctionem]
Kuṟuntokai 88. Maturaik Katakkaṇṇaṉ: the confidante / SHE
Kuṟuntokai 130. Veḷḷi Vīti(yār): the confidante / SHE

div.p: [The hero] expressing his desire [for a meeting] entreatingly when her companion has [her] doubts; her companion then questioning [the hero]; [the hero] creating a mutual understanding; [her companion] determining [the intention of the hero]; [the confidante] putting him at a distance; [her companion?] saying "Do not hide being one who knows [by saying] "I do not know what is pointed out"; [her companion] speaking [to him about] what is not intended; [her companion] speaking fabrications; [her companion] saying she is difficult [to approach]; [her companion] saying "You speak [to her]!"; [her companion] jokingly comforting [the hero]; [the hero] saying "Speak [to me] without joking!"; [her companion] saying "We are not appropriate for this, you great man!"; [her companion] demonstrating the uniqueness of the giftThis is not in prasise of the gift, but rather highlighting the fact that it is not unique; [her companion] saying "It is not suitable to touch [her] body."; [her compainion] saying "Knowing her state, I will take [the gift]."; speaking of the Palymyra-horse; [her companion] opposing [it]; [her companion] accepting the gift; [her companion] speaking [to the heroine] entreatingly [on his behalf]; [her companion speaking of the hero] leaving in shame; [her companion] persuading [the heroine] to accept [the hero's] request by spaking forcefully; [her companion] kindly accepting [the leaf-skirt]; [her companion] entrusting the leaf-skirt [to the heroine]; [the heroine] accepting the gift; [her companion] saying that [the acceptence of the gift] had come true; speaking about the desired [meeting-]place; [her companion] leaving with [knowledge of] the tryst; getting dressing and being ready [to return]; [the hero] speaking [to her companion] about [the heroine's] state; and leaving with her companion are [the situaions of] the daytime tryst.
e-tu. tōḻiyiṟ kūṭṭattup pakaṟ kuṟi yām āṟuṇarttutaṉutaliṟṟu.
The quoted [cūttiram] intends to make known the way in which the daytime meeting place for a union [by means of] her companion occurs.
pāṅkiyai yuṇarntatu mutal ākak koṇṭu peyarntatīṟākac collap paṭṭaṉa vellān tōḻiyiṉ ākiya pakaṟ kuṟik kūṭṭam ām eṉṟa vāṟu.

All of the things mentioned, beginning with 'making known [his desire] to the tōḻi' and ending with '[the tōḻi] taking [the heroine] and departing', are the union at the daytime meeting-place on account of the tōḻi.
[The hero] informing her companion [of his desire].

lg.l: Cf. PK 75 (73 in some editions).puṉaiyiḻai yāyamoṭu pūmpan teṟiyavu

div.p: eṉpatu vēṟu pāṭu kaṇṭu pāṅki yaiyuṟṟatu.
Her comapnion, having seen the changes [in the heroine's state], expresses doubts [about their cause].

lg.l: Cf. PK59-61 for poems where he asks the heroine and her compainion whether a stag has passed by. In PK60 and 61, the stag has been wounded by an arrow.ampumukaṅ kiḻitta vempuṇ vāya

div.p: eṉpatu kavarntu niṉṟa tōḻiyai mati yuṭaṉ paṭuppāṉ uṟṟut tōḻiyun talaimakaḷum uṭaṉ āya vaḻit talaimakaṉ viṉāyatu.

lg.l: Cf. PK72 where the hero asks the way to heroine's village.uraimi ṉīrma ṉemakkē varaiyiṭai

div.p: The confidante doubts [the intentions of] the hero.
The confidante determines [the intentions of] the hero.
[The confidante] puts the hero at a distance.

lg.l: yāṅkā kiyarōākiyarō is relatively common as a rhetorical question in Caṅkam Tamil, employing the optative - cf. KT40 - in this case something like 'where will it fall?'. I am not quite sure why UVC felt the need to emend in this case. Perhaps he thought ākiyar was an epicene form and thus corrected it to the neuter singular, though this would be extremely surprising given his breadth of knowledge. vēntaṉiṉ ṉaruḷē

div.p: It seems as though [the confidante] does not know [the hero's intentions].
[The confidante] saying, "Do not hide!" [to the hero].
The companion speaking about something which the hero does not intend [to discuss]
[The confidante] says "She is difficult [to speak to]" [to the hero].
[The confidante] says "Tell [the heroine] your request yourself!" [to the hero].

eṉpatu kaiyuṟai veḷumaiThis is recorded as a variant spelling for the more common eḷimai 'easiness' in the TL. This follows a larger pattern of i/u spelling variants in this manuscript, possibly indicating a regional dialect and thus place of production. kūṟiyatu.

lg.l: pūmeṉ ṟaṇṭaḻai koḷkuvaṉkoḷḷuvaṉ has no attestations, but can we hypothosise its existence as a participial noun formed in the same way as coḷḷuvāḷ? Both are mono-syllabic CVC verbal roots. For now I am favouring the known form. purintē

div.p: [The confidante] tells [the hero how the heroine] accepted the gift.
[The confidante] speaks about the place for the daytime tryst.

eṉpatu talaimakaḷaik kuṟiyiṉI think kuṟi referred to both the tryst and the location of the tryst and the early theoreticians and commentators used them quite interchangeably. Perhaps later editors sought to standardise and narrow the meaning of the word into just the tryst, hense the addition of va(yiṉ). iṟuttip peyarntatu.
[The confidante] places the heroine at the meeting-place and leaves.
The hero informs the confidante about [the heroine's] readiness.

standOff.note: Cf. TP99i.12: tōḻiyayaikkuṟaiyuṟum pakutiyum
Cf. IA5.3: irantukuṟai yuṟutalum kiḻavōṉ mēṟṟē
Cf. TP125i.1: kuṟaiyuṟa vuṇartaṉ muṉṉurṟa vuṇartal
Cf. IA7.1: muṉṉuṟa vuṇartal kuṟaiyuṟa vuṇartal
Cf. TP125i.3: matiyuṭam paṭuttal
Cf. IA6.5: matiyuṭam paṭuttaṟku...
Cf. IA12.2: cēṭpaṭa niṟuttalum
Cf. IA12.8: paṭaittumoḻi kiḷaiviyuṅ
Cf. TP99i.20: maṭal mā kūṟum
Cf. TP171i.1: taḻīik kōṭal
Cf. TP128i: kuṟiyeṉap paṭuva tiraviṉum pakaliṉu | maṟit tōṉṟu māṟṟa teṉpa
Cf. IA18: kuṟiyeṉap paṭuva tiraviṉum pakaliṉu | maṟiyak kiḷant viṭameṉa moḻipa
Cf. TP130i: pakaṟpuṇar kaḷaṉē paṟaṉeṉa maḻipa | vavaḷaṟi vuṇara varuvaḻi yāṉa
Cf. IA20: pakaḵuṟi tāṉē yikappiṉum vuraiyār
In keeping with the pattern from previous cūttirams, the IAC is not treated as a source for the cūttiram. It is cited where appropriate in the commmentary.
Unlike the commentary to the previous cūttiram, there is no enumeration of speech situations here and so there are no sources or parallels.
Cf. IAC7, p.67-68: 'ivaṭku ivvēṟupāṭu teyvattiṉāṉ āyiṟṟukkollō' eṉavum, 'makkaḷiṉāṉ āyiṟṟukkollō' eṉavum
Cf. IAC7, p.71-72: avaḷatu vēṟupāṭu kaṇṭu, 'teyvattiṉāṉ āyiṟṟukkollō! maṟṟoruvāṟṟāṉāyiṟṟukkollō!' eṉa aiyuṟṟu niṟpatu;
From this point on, sources from the IAC will be provided for the koḷus in the TNVC. They are the equivalent to a list of speech situations such as that in the commentary to TNV16.

The IAC names two situations where the confidante questions the cause of the bodily changes she has noticed in the heroine. I have provided both. Note that the poem cited in the TNVC is similar to the PK verse quoted to exmaplify the second occurrence of this doubt.
Cf. IAC6, p.67: avaḷatu aṟaviṉai oruppaṭukkum eṉavē, muṉ kavarntu niṉratu eṉpatu pōntatu.
Cf. IAC6, p.68: iṉi 'ataṟkoṇṭu taḻaiyum kaṇṇiyum koṇṭu piṉṉilai muṉiyātu irantu piṉṉiṟkiṉṟāṉ, ivvuṭaiya kuṟai yārmāṭṭatu kollō'
Cf. IAC6, p.68: iṉi 'vēṟuppaṭṭātu ivaṉkāraṇam pōlum, ivaṉ irantu piṉṉiṟkiṉṟatu ivaḷkāraṇam pōlum'
Cf. IAC12, p.87: iṉi, aṟiyāḷ pōṟalum eṉpatu - talaimakaṉ taḻaiyum kaṇṇiyum koṇṭu piṉṉiṉṟaviṭattu, 'nammāṟ collap paṭuvāḷai aṟiyēṉ' eṉṉum
Cf. IAC12, p.86: eṉavē, 'maṟaiyātu viṭṭaviṭattu muṭivuṇṭu' eṉṟaḷ eṉpatu.
Cf. IAC12, p.88: kuṟiyāḷ kūṟalum eṉpatu - ... avaṟṟai ēṟṟuk koḷḷātu maṟṟoṉṟu colli nīṅkuvatu
Cf. IAC12, p.87: 'nīyē ceṉṟu niṉkuṟai collāy'
Cf. IAC12, p.87: avaṉ irantu piṉṉiṉṟaviṭattu māyamāṉa puṇarttuc collukiṉratu, iḵtu ulakattu nikaḻvateṉṟaṉṟālō eṉṟu avaṉoṭu nakāniṉṟē...
Cf. IAC12, p.91: iṉi ivvakaiyuñ collum: 'nīyir periyīr, yām ciṟiyōm, nammōṭu emmiṭaik kaṭṭurai poruntātu' eṉṉum
Cf. IAC8, p.76:maṭalēṟuvaṉ eṉṟirāl
Cf. IAC8, p.76: 'aṉṟiyum, "maṭalēṟuvaṉ" eṉṟirāl, ammaṭalēṟap paṭuvatu uruvu eḻutikkoṇ ṭaṉṟē ēṟuvatu; namakku uruveḻuttal āmō?'

What is given one short identification in the TNVC koḷu - that the confidante is trying to prevent him from riding the palmyra-horse - is expanded into multiple situations in the IAC, like the one cited here, relevant to this poem.
Cf. IAC10, p.79: melitāka collik kuṟainayapppikkumāṟu
Cf. IAC10, p.80: valitāka collik kuṟainayappikkumāṟu

In practice, the IAC combines this sub-situation in the TNVC and the previous one. The confidante tells the heroine how the hero came the day before, and on seeing a male animal either play with or protect its female partner, he feels shame that he is unable to do so and leaves. One sees this in the quoted poems.
Cf. IAC18, p.104: 'iṉṉa iṭattu vara' eṉru kuṟippiṉāṉ uṇarttum

I take the reading from the paper-copy here. ṉ and ḷ are easily confusable in Tamil script and since we would expect the heroine to be left by her friend at the meeting place, following the IAC, I think this is a worthwhile deviation.
Cf. IAC5, p.82: paṇinta moḻiyaṉṟē, 'ittaḻai nalla, ikkaṇṇi nalla' eṉṟu iṅṅaṉam kaiyuṟai pārāṭṭic ceṉṟu niṟṟal;
Cf. IAC6, p.66: 'iṅkē cilamā pōntaṉa uḷavē'
CF. IAC12, p.89: nīr uṭaiyatōr kuṟai uṇṭēyeṉiṉ, akaṉṟu niṉṟu muṭittukkoḷḷaṟpāṟṟu eṉṉum
Cf. PK109.4:...yārkaṇṇatō aṇṇal cintaṉaiyē

Cf. PK110: poṟikeḻu kaṇṭai vaṭavarai melvaittup pūmiyellām | neṟikeḻu ceṅkōḷ naṭāneṭu māṟaṉnel vēliveṉṟāṉ | veṟikamaḻ pūṅkaṇṇik kāṉal viḷaiyāṭ ṭayaraniṉṟa | ceṟikuḻa lārpalar yārkaṇṇatō aṇṇal iṉṉaruḷē ||

The cited TNVC poem echoes the final question from both PK verses quoted in the IAC, especially PK110. The poem as a whole may well be based on PK109. The basic question of "Upon whom, out of these beautiful girls with fragrant curls, does your grace lie?" is there in both.
Cf. PK78.4, (IAC7, p.73):...oṉṟē iruvarkkum iṉṉuyirē

There is a clear similarity between the wording and idea expressed by this phrase in the PK and TNV, however withing the wider structure of the, it seems as thought the TNVC has re-organised the IAC. In Nakkīraṉār's text, this situation immediately follows the condidante's doubt. In the TNV she is certainly already aware of the relationship.
Cf. PK105.4 (IAC12, p.86): eṉṉai maṟaittiv viṭattiya lātukol eṉṉiyatē
Cf. PK105.3-4 (IAC12, p.86): vantataṉāṉ | uṇṭē muṭittal eṉakku maṟaippiṉum uḷḷakattē
Cf. IAC12, p.88-9: ivviṭam eṉṉaiyarāṉun taṉṉaiyarāṉum palkālum pukutarappaṭumāl; avar nammaik kaṇṭāl ētañcayvar, kūṟṟiṉum kaṭuñciṉatta rākalāṉ... akaṉṟu niṉru
Recall that 'putting [the hero] at a distance' also fell under this general category in the IAC, whereas TNV has reorganised.
Cf. IAC12, p.90: neṟinīr iruṅkaḻi nīlamum cūṭāḷ | poṟimāṇ variyalavaṉ āḷatlum āṭāḷ | ciṟunutal veyarvarumpac cintiyā niṉṟāṭku | eṟinīrttaṇ cīrppayāṉ eṉcollic celkō||

The main rhetorical question of this anonymous poem - the confidante wondering what she can tell the heroine - and the image of girls playing in the sand are the same in both poems. The poem is also quoted in Nacci's commentary to TP23, which UVC in turn provides as a footnote for this poem in his TNV edition.
Cf. IAC12, p.90: 'nīyir viruntiṉirākalāṉ avaḷatu arumaiyum perumaiyum aṟiyīraṉṟē, ..., emakkuk kaṇkūṭākac celvatōr tevyamallaḷō?'

Cf. IAC12, p.91: nerunalu muṉṉāḷ elliyum oruciṟaip | putuvai yākaliṟ kiḷattal nāṇi | nēriḻai vaḷaittōḷ niṉtōḻi ceyak | aruyir varuttaṅ kaḷaiyā yōveṉa | eṟkuṟai yuṟutir āyiṟ coṟkuṟai | empatta teḷiyaḷ allaḷ emakkōr | kaḷkāṇ kaḷavuḷ allaḷō peruma | vāykōṉ miḷakiṉ malayaṅ koḻuṅkoṭi | tuñcupuli varippuṟan taivarum | mañcucūḻ maṇvariai maṉṉavaṉ makaḷē||

The first five lines of this anonymous poem, also quoted by Nacci in his commentary to TP23, is the same as what is transmitted in the KK. Then there seems to have been some cross-fertilisaton of different strands or simply of different poems. The final two lines of poem found in the TNVC, are the same as those in the KK, but the IAC and TPna different. Lines 6-7 of the IAC poem, are very similar in content to the TNVC poem. The most striking similarity is to the prose preamble to the IAC poem, which mirrors the content of the TNVC poem almost exactly, and which I therefore think is its primary source.

app.rdg: nerunalu muṉṉā ḷellaiyu moruciṟaip putumai yātaliṟ kiḷatta ṉāṇi nēriṟai vaḷaittōḷuṉ ṟōḻi ceyta vāruyir varuttaṅ kaḷaiyā yōveṉa veṟkuṟai yuṟutirāyiṟ coṟkuṟai

nerunalu muṉṉā ḷellaiyu moruciṟaip putumai yātali kiḷatta ṉāṇi nēriṟai vaḷaittōḷuṉ ṟōḻil ceyta
vāruyir varuttaṅ kaḷaiyā yōveṉa veṟkuṟai yuṟutirāyiṟ coṟkuṟai

nerunalu muṉṉā ḷellaiyu moruciṟaip putumai yātaliṟ kiḷatta ṉāṇi nēriṟai vaḷaittōḷuṉ ṟōḻil ceyta
vāruyir varuttaṅ kaḷaiyā yōveṉa veṟkuṟai yuṟutirāyiṟ coṟkuṟai
nerunalu muṉṉā ḷellaiyu moruciṟaip putuvai yātaliṟ kiḷatta ṉāṇi nēriṟai vaḷaittōḷuṉ ṟōḻi ceyta vāruyir varuttaṅ kaḷaiyā yōveṉa veṟkuṟai yuṟutirāyiṟ coṟkuṟai vampa

standOff.note: Cf. PK107.2-4 (IAC12, p.87):...an taṇpūmpotiyil | vēyē aṉaiyameṉ tōḷikku niṉkaṇ melivuṟunōy | nīyē uraiyāy viraiyāy alaṇkal neṭuntakaiyē||
Cf. NA45.9-11 (IAC12, p. 91): perunīr viḷaiyuḷeñ ciṟunal vāḻkkai | nammoṭu puraivatō aṉṟē | emma ṉūriṟ cemmalum uṭaittē||
Note specifically the quotation in the TNVC of the phrase at the end of line 10 from NA45 - puraivatō vaṉṟē.

Cf. IAC12, p.92: nīṭunīrk kāṉal nerunalu nittilaṅkoṇ ṭaiyavantīr | kōṭuyar veṇmaṇaṟ coṟkaiyam mūrivaṟṟāṟ kuṟaivilamyām | āṭum kaḻaṅkum aṇiviḷaṅkum ammaṉaiyum piṟavumellām | pāṭiya vaippaṉ vumpantarp paṭuvaṉavum paṉinīrmuttam||

Cf. IAC12, p.92: nuṉṉaittañ ciṟṟil muḻaṅkukaṭa lōtam mūḻkippeyar | aṉṉaik kuraippaṉ aṟivāykaṭa lēyeṉ ṟalaṟippēeuñ | taṉmai maṭavar taṇantukutta veṇmuttan takaicūḻkāṉaṟ | puṉṉai yarumpēyppapēvāraip pētuṟukkum pukārēyemmūr||
Though neither poem is particularly close in their wording, the central idea is shared - the girl are not impressed by pearls since there are plenty where they are from.

Cf. PK127 (IAC12, p.127): kainnilat tuccilai yāṟkaṇai cintik kaṟuttetirntār | cennilat tuppaṭac cīṟiya kōṉceḻun taṇpotiyil | innilat tammalai mēlavov vāvirun taṇcilampā | ennilat temmalai mēlaic cantaṉat tīrntaḻaiyē||

My impression is that the author of the TNVC was playing with the meaning of the PK source. The TNVC poem is sarcastic and its subtext is exactly that expressed in the PK - giving us a gift of flowers found on our mountains is not good enough.
This is also quoted, with no variation, in the IAC (p.76.).
Cf. IAC8, p.76: 'maṭaleṟuvaṉ eṉṟirāl, namakku maṭaleṟutal iyaivatukollō, eṉṉai, nīyir pēraruḷiṉir ākalāṉ'

Cf. PK81 (IAC8, p.76): palamaṉṉu puḷḷiṉam pārppuñ ciṉaiyum avaiyaḻiya | ulamaṉṉu tōḷaṇṇal ūrak koḷāykol olitiraicūḻ | nilamaṉṉaṉ nēriyaṉ māṟaṉ neṭuṅkaḷat taṭṭatiṅkaṭ | kulamaṉṉaṉ kaṉṉik kulaivaḷar peṇṇaik koḻumaṭalē||

Cf. PK83 (IAC, p.77): kaḷicēr kaḷiṟṟuk kaḻalneṭu māṟaṉ kaṭaiyal veṉṟa | teḷicēr oḷimutta veṇkuṭai maṉṉaṉteṉ ṉuṭiayāḷ | kiḷicēr moḻiyum karuṅkuḻal nāṟṟamuṅ kēṭpiṉaiya | eḷitō eḻuta eḻutippiṉ ūrak eḻilmaṭal||
Cf. PK120.1-2 (IAC12, p.92): vēḻam viṉavutir meṉpūn taḻaiyum koṇarntuniṟṟir | āḻu muṭaiya karumattir pōṟir aṇaintakalīr |
Cf. IAC10, p.79: avvāṟu karuti poyttēṟku avar ataṉai meyyeṉṟu karutikkoṇṭu ceṉṟār; tām poyyaṟiyāmaiyiṉ; aṉṉār iṉṟu varuvar
Cf. PK87.4 (IAC10, p.79):...aṟiyēṉ uraippator poymmoḻiyē
Cf. PK92.2-4 (IAC10, p.80):...yāṉ coṉṉa poyyaimey yeṉṟakalāṉ | perumpāṉ maiyumiṉṟu vārā viṭāṉvariṟ peramarkkaṭ | curumpār karuṅkuḻal vāyiṟ yēṉiṉic colluvatē

Cf. IAC10, p.81: nerunalaināḷāl ikkāṉaluḷ vantu eṉṉai etirppaṭṭut taṉ tuṉai puṟantaruvatōr alavaṉaik kaṇṭu, "ituvākātē aṟivum āṇmaiyumāvatu!" eṉa ataṉai naṉkumatittu āṟṟāṉāy eṉṉaiyum nōkki alavaṉaiyum nōkki, 'uṇarviṉai eṉkaṇṇum avvalavaṉ kaṇṇum oḻiyap pōyiṉaṉ'

Cf. PK96 (IAC, p.81): pāṭuñ ciṟaivaṇ ṭaṟaipoḻiliṟ pāḻippaṟ ṟāvaracar | ōṭun tiṟaṇkaṇṭa kōṉkaṉṉik kāṉal uṟutuṇaiyōṭu | āṭum alavaṟ pukaḻnteṉṉai nōkki aṟivaḻiya | nītu niṉaintceṉ ṟaṉneṉṉal āṇkor neṭuntakaiyē||
Cf. Cilap.7, 31 (IAC10, p.79): puṇartuṇaiyō ḷāṭum poṟiyalavaṉ nōkki | iṇaraitaip pūṅkāṉal eṉṉaiyum nōkki | uṇarvoḻiyap pōṉa olitirainīrc cērppaṉ | vaṇarpuri aimpālāy vaṇṇam uṇarēṉāl||

Cf. PK100 (IAC11, p.84): cilaimicai vatta puliyum kayaluñceṉ ṟōṅkucempoṉ | malaimicai vaitta perumāṉ varōtayaṉ vañciyaṉṉāḷcēr | mulaimicai vaittumeṉ tōḷmēṟ kaṭāyttaṉ moypūṅkuḻal | talaimicai vaittuṅkoṇ ṭāḷaṇṇal nītanta taṇtaḻaiyē||

Cf. PK101 (IAC11, p.84): kaḻutu karuti paḷiyak kalinītk kaṭaiayalveṉṟa | viḻutu paṭuneṭu vēlmaṉṉaṉ īrmpuṉal kūṭalaṉṉaḷ | toḻutu talaimicai vaittuṇkoṇ ṭallḷvaṇṭun tumpuliyumtēṉ | koḻutu malarneṟun tāraṇṇak nītanta koytaḻaiyē||

Neither of the poems bear a great resemblence to the one quoted in the TNVC, however they are certainly used to exemplify the same situation. One also find the same poem quoted for the same situtaion in the AV (see AVC 149.) - telling the hero about how the heroine accepted the leaf skirt.

Cf. PK141 (IAC18, p.105): maruḷpōl ciṟaivaṇṭu pāṭ nilavaṉṉa vārmaṇalmēl | iruḷpōl koḻuniḻalaṟ pāyaṟin tārkaḷkiṉ rīṅkamiḻiṉ kōṉ | poruḷpōl iṉtāyp pakaḻmaṉṉaṉ māṟaṉ potiyiliṉ | aruḷpōṟ kuḷirntaṉṉa muntuṉṉum nīrtteṅkaḷ āṭṭimē||

Cf. PK142 (IAC18, p.105): kāviyan taṇtuṟai cūḻntu kaṭaiyaṟ kaṟuttavarmēl | tūviyam peytavaṉ toṇṭivaṇ ṭārpuṉṉait tūmalarkaḷ | tāviya veṇmaṇaṟ ṟāyaṟin tārkaṭkut taṇtamiḻiṉ | āviyum pōl iṉitāy uḷateṅkaḷ āṭṭimē||
Cf. IAC18, p.105: tōḻi talamiakaḷai kuṟiyiṭattu koṇṭuceṉṟu, 'yāṉ ceṅkāntaḷpūk koṇṭu varuvēṉ, avviṭattut teycamuṭaittu, niṉṉāl varappaṭātu, nī avvaḷavum ippoḻilakattē nil' eṉṟu niṟīi nīṅkum.
Cf. PK143.1 (IAC18, p.105): añciṟai vaṇṭaṟai kāntaḷam pōtuceṉ ṟiyāṉtaruveṉ
Cf. PK144.1-2 (IAC18, p.105): nīvarai kōtaiyiṅ kēnilniṉ ṉālavaraṟ pālataṉṟu | tīviri kāntaḷceṉ ṟiyāṉtaru vēṉteyvam aṅkuṭaittāl |
KT1 is also quoted in the IAC to exemplify this situation.
Cf. IAC18, p.105: puṇarcciyiṟutikkaṇ tōḻivantu, 'niṉ kaipōlak kāntaḷ malarntaṉa koṇṭuvantēṉ, emperumāṭṭi, nīṭṭittāḷeṉṟu cīṟiyaruḷātu pōntaruḷ' eṉṟu, avaḷai koṇṭu pōy āyaveḷḷatoṭuṅ kūṭṭam
